entries.title: Singapore central bank eases monetary policy, first time since March 2020
entries.snippet: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has loosened its monetary policy for the first time since March 2020 due to slower-than-expected inflation and economic growth. The central bank, which controls monetary policy through the exchange rate, has slightly reduced the slope of the S$NEER policy band, allowing for a modest appreciation of the Singapore dollar. Core inflation is now forecasted between 1.0% and 2.0% for 2025, down from the previously expected 1.5% to 2.5%. Headline inflation forecasts remain at 1.5%-2.5%. Singapore's GDP growth was 4% in 2024, surpassing the initial projection of 3.5%, but is expected to slow to 1%-3% in 2025. This decision marks a significant shift as MAS had tightened policy five times since October 2021 to combat pandemic-related inflation and geopolitical uncertainties. The Singapore dollar stabilized against the U.S. dollar, and the domestic stock index rose by 0.7% following the announcement.

entries.title: Singapore central bank keeps monetary policy settings unchanged
entries.snippet:
On July 30, 2025, Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), announced that it would maintain its existing monetary policy settings, following a stronger-than-expected economic performance in the second quarter. Specifically, MAS will keep the current rate of appreciation of its exchange rate-based policy band, known as the Nominal Effective Exchange Rate (S$NEER), unchanged, along with the width and center of the band.

Earlier in the year, MAS had implemented two policy easings, and it now believes the current stance provides sufficient flexibility to address any medium-term risks to price stability. The decision came amid divided expectations among economists: half of the twelve analysts surveyed by Reuters anticipated no policy change, while the other half predicted an additional easing.

entries.title: Singapore eases monetary policy for first time in 4 years
entries.snippet: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has eased monetary policy for the first time in four years due to increasing trade policy frictions under Donald Trump’s renewed US presidency and moderating domestic inflation. This change involves slowing the appreciation rate of the Singapore dollar against a basket of trading partners' currencies. Unlike other central banks, MAS controls monetary policy through exchange rates rather than domestic interest rates, and this move effectively lowers borrowing costs in the trade-dependent economy. Recent data showed Singapore’s core consumer price index rose just 1.8% in December, prompting MAS to lower its 2025 inflation forecast to 1-2%. The MAS anticipates slower GDP growth in 2025, projecting a decrease from 4% in 2024 to 1-3%. Despite initial declines, the Singapore dollar later traded at S$1.3526 per US dollar.

entries.title: Singapore keeps monetary policy unchanged as trade tensions ease
entries.snippet:
Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has decided to maintain its current monetary policy, keeping the rate of appreciation of its exchange rate-based policy band unchanged. This decision comes amid improved global trade conditions and stronger-than-expected economic growth in the second quarter, which showed a 1.4% quarter-on-quarter GDP increase, helping the country avoid a technical recession. The choice to maintain policy contrasts with analyst expectations, which were evenly split between a policy hold and further easing.

MAS cited easing trade tensions and more stable financial conditions since April as factors reducing the need for additional stimulus. Despite this, uncertainties remain, particularly around 2026, and Singapore’s growth is expected to slow in the latter half of 2025 as the impact of frontloaded exports wanes. Core inflation has dropped to 0.6% year-on-year in June 2025 from 5.5% in early 2023. While OCBC and Maybank economists noted two-way inflation risks from tariff impacts and geopolitical shifts, Maybank forecasted Singapore’s 2025 GDP growth at 3.2%, higher than the government's current 0.0–2.0% projection.

entries.title: Financial crisis: action taken by central banks and governments
entries.snippet:
In response to the global financial crisis of 2008, central banks and governments worldwide implemented a series of significant interventions to stabilize their economies. The European Union introduced a comprehensive plan to boost liquidity, underwrite bank debt, and recapitalize distressed banks, emulating the UK's £500bn package. Member states also raised the minimum guarantee on bank savings. 

Britain effectively nationalized RBS, HBOS, and Lloyds, extended liquidity schemes, guaranteed new bank debt, and prohibited short-selling. Countries like Ireland, Greece, and Germany increased guarantees on bank deposits and provided substantial funds to recapitalize banks and secure debt issuance. Denmark and France also injected capital into their banks and banned short-selling.

Non-EU countries took similar measures. Iceland nationalized its major banks and sought external loans. Russia allocated significant liquidity and loan support to banks. Italy, Spain, Austria, and several other nations expanded guarantees on deposits, raised capital for banks, and imposed short-selling restrictions. 

The US's $700bn bail-out was the most considerable intervention, also raising bank deposit guarantees. Canada, Australia, South Korea, and several Asian and Middle Eastern countries took steps including interest rate cuts, liquidity provision, and increased depositor protections to mitigate the crisis's impact.

entries.title: UK interest rates kept at record lows , Greek parliament approves pension deal -as it happened
entries.snippet:
The article highlights key financial events, such as the Greek parliament's approval of a pension deal and the Bank of England's decision to keep interest rates at a record low of 0.25%. The Greek parliament's vote to approve a controversial Christmas bonus for pensioners saw 196 in favor, despite the abstention of the New Democracy party. This move by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is part of the ongoing debate over anti-austerity measures, with various political parties, including the far-right Golden Dawn, supporting it.

In the broader European context, markets gained after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time in a year, signaling three more increases in the coming year. This rate hike strengthened the dollar, which generally benefits banking shares. Despite this, commodity stocks fell due to a stronger greenback.

Greece's controversial pension bonus, involving pre-Christmas fiscal gifts, led creditors to put debt relief on hold. Meanwhile, European markets also reacted to the Fed's decision, influencing banking and financial shares, while gold prices hit their lowest since February 2016 due to rising interest rates. 

Further, Swiss central bank maintained its interest rates at minus 0.75%, noting political uncertainties including Brexit negotiations. Sterling's recovery influenced the UK's inflation forecasts, leading the Bank of England to suggest a possible rise in inflation for 2017.

entries.title: Fitch affirms US credit at 'AA+', rising debt a ratings constraint
entries.snippet: Fitch has reaffirmed the U.S. credit rating at "AA+" as of August 2025, acknowledging the nation's robust, high-income economy and its financial resilience due to the dollar’s dominance as a global reserve currency. However, the ratings agency expressed ongoing concern about the U.S.'s high fiscal deficits and growing debt burden, amplified by insufficient policy action to address these issues or the costs associated with an aging population. Despite a projected narrowing of the general government deficit to 6.9% of GDP in 2025—down from 7.7% in 2024—thanks to economic growth, strong market performance, and substantial tariff revenue increases, Fitch warned that debt levels are expected to rise long-term, with debt-to-GDP reaching 127% by 2027. The agency also flagged the country’s growing vulnerability to economic shocks. Fitch's outlook remains stable, even as other rating agencies, including Moody’s and S&P Global, have also downgraded or confirmed the U.S. rating due to similar concerns, with tariffs viewed as a partial fiscal buffer.

The decision is attributed to a perceived decline in governance standards, particularly in fiscal and debt matters, despite recent bipartisan agreements. Persistent political standoffs over the debt limit, high levels of US debt, complex budgeting processes, and long-term funding issues for social security and Medicare are cited as key reasons. Economic uncertainties, rising debt levels, the Federal Reserve's tightening cycle, and potential recession risks were also factors. While this downgrade alone may not significantly impact the overall creditworthiness or borrowing costs of the US, it could affect financial markets and increase interest in US debt. entries.title: The United States loses its triple-A credit rating at Moody's over rising federal debt
entries.snippet: On May 16, 2025, Moody's downgraded the United States' credit rating from Aaa to Aa1, citing rising federal debt and interest costs. This marked the loss of the last triple-A rating the U.S. held, following previous downgrades by Fitch Ratings in 2023 and S&P Global Ratings in 2011. Moody's explained that successive administrations and Congress have repeatedly failed to implement effective measures to curb large budget deficits and rising entitlement costs, projecting continuing fiscal deterioration over the next decade. Despite the downgrade, Moody’s shifted the U.S. outlook from negative to stable, acknowledging the nation’s strong institutional framework, large and resilient economy, and the U.S. dollar’s global reserve status. President Donald Trump has vowed to reduce the national debt, which has surpassed $36 trillion. Countries maintaining Aaa ratings with Moody’s include the European Union, Canada, and Germany, while Austria and Finland share the new Aa1 rating with the U.S.

entries.title: Moody's strips U.S. government of top credit rating, citing Washington's failure to rein in debt
entries.snippet: Moody's Ratings downgraded the United States' credit rating from Aaa to Aa1, citing the federal government's persistent failure to control its growing debt. Despite acknowledging the resilience of the U.S. economy and the dollar's role as a global reserve currency, Moody's warned that federal deficits are expected to rise to nearly 9% of GDP by 2035, from 6.4% in 2024. This increase is attributed to higher interest payments, surging entitlement costs, and relatively weak revenue growth. Extending former President Donald Trump's 2017 tax cuts, a Republican priority, would contribute an additional $4 trillion to the primary deficit over the next decade. Moody's is the last of the major credit agencies to issue a downgrade, following Standard & Poor's in 2011 and Fitch in 2023. Political gridlock continues to hinder deficit-reduction efforts, with Republicans opposing tax hikes and Democrats resisting spending cuts. Efforts to pass a significant package of tax breaks and spending reductions failed in the House Budget Committee, as a coalition of hard-right Republicans and Democrats opposed the measure due to disagreements over Medicaid cuts and green energy incentives.

entries.title: Singapore economists see growth of 3.6% in 2024, monetary policy unchanged in January
entries.snippet: Singapore's economy is anticipated to grow by 3.6% in 2024, surpassing the previous forecast of 2.6%, according to a survey by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). For the final quarter of 2024, a growth rate of 3.1% is expected, with an overall growth rate of 2.6% predicted for 2025. This revised forecast follows the trade ministry's recent adjustment of its GDP growth projection for 2024 to 3.5%, based on stronger-than-expected third-quarter growth of 5.4%. Despite the uptick in economic growth and decreasing inflation, the majority of economists expect MAS to maintain its current monetary policy in the upcoming reviews in January, April, and July. Headline and core inflation for 2024 are projected at 2.5% and 2.8%, respectively, slightly lower than previous estimates. Core inflation for the last quarter of 2024 and headline and core inflation for 2025 are expected to be in the range of 1.5% to 1.9%. Only 33% of polled economists foresee a loosening of monetary policy in January.

entries.title: Singapore's low inflation not enough for a January easing, analysts say
entries.snippet: Despite slowing inflation creating potential for Singapore's central bank to ease monetary policy in January, analysts predict the bank may wait until later in 2025. This delay would allow for assessment of incoming U.S. President Donald Trump's policies. The expected November inflation data shows core rates steady at October's three-year low of 2.1%. Analysts from DBS Bank and Moody's Analytics suggest the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will likely adopt a cautious approach akin to the U.S. Federal Reserve, waiting for concrete policies rather than speculative responses. The MAS uses the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) for policy adjustments, utilizing the slope, mid-point, and width of the policy band. A recent survey indicates a reduced expectation for a January policy easing, with some analysts like Maybank's Chua Hak Bin predicting a potential inflation drop below 2%, and a subsequent policy review influenced by global trade disruptions and lower import prices due to Trump's tariffs.

thoughts.summary: Economic and political factors impacting SGD
thoughts.content: To explain the SGD/USD dynamics, economic factors include: differences in monetary policy (Fed vs. MAS), inflation, and MAS's adjustments, along with Singapore's current account surplus and global trade growth connections. Commodity cycles (like oil) also play a role. Politically, U.S. fiscal and trade policies, China's growth, and Singapore's domestic stability can influence the exchange rate. We'll present a clear, objective analysis with a chart for clarity.

parts:
Here’s the 20-year story of USD/SGD (values are **SGD per USD**—a lower number means a stronger SGD):

- **Start vs now.** Annual average in **2005** was **1.6639**; by **2024** it was **1.3363** (≈**-19.7%**). As of **17 Oct 2025**, the daily rate was **~1.295** (≈**-22%** from 2005). citeturn5view0turn4view0

- **Pattern (2005→2025).**
  - **2005–07:** broad USD softness; USD/SGD fell from ~1.66 to ~1.51. citeturn5view0
  - **2008–09 (GFC):** risk-off and policy easing in Singapore (band flattened in Oct-2008; mid-point re-centred lower in Apr-2009) pushed USD/SGD up near mid-1.4s, then back down. citeturn7search9turn7search6
  - **2010–11:** recovery + MAS tightening → SGD strengthened; annual **2011** average **1.2565**. citeturn5view0
  - **2015–16:** Fed “liftoff” & two MAS slope cuts (Jan & Oct-2015) then **0% slope** (Apr-2016) → USD/SGD rose to the high-1.3s. citeturn8search0turn8search2turn8search5
  - **2018:** growth upturn and MAS normalisation → USD/SGD drifted lower (~1.35). citeturn5view0
  - **2020 (COVID):** MAS set **0% slope** and re-centred lower; risk-off lifted USD broadly; USD/SGD around **1.38** on annual average. citeturn7search13turn5view0
  - **2021–22:** MAS tightened **five times in 12 months**, but the **aggressive Fed** made the USD broadly strong; USD/SGD firmed (2022 annual **1.379**). citeturn0search6turn0search7turn2search2
  - **2023–24:** MAS paused; USD strength ebbed; USD/SGD eased to **1.34** (2024 annual). citeturn10search14turn5view0
  - **2025 YTD:** MAS **eased** (Jan; slope trimmed) and later **held**; despite that, USD/SGD is **~1.29–1.30** into October—helped by better trade tone and softer U.S. dollar episodes. citeturn3news20turn3news21turn4view0

---

## Why it moved: Economics first

1) **Singapore’s exchange-rate regime (the big structural driver).**  
Singapore targets a **trade-weighted S$NEER** in a **basket-band-crawl** system; policy is set by the **slope, width, and mid-point** of the band. This framework aims for low, stable inflation and tends to allow a **modest long-run SGD appreciation** against the basket—hence USD/SGD’s downward drift over two decades. MAS also **intervenes** to keep S$NEER within the band. citeturn3search1turn3search2turn3search3turn0search10

2) **Interest-rate differentials & global USD cycles.**  
When U.S. rates rise sharply relative to Asia (e.g., **2015–16** liftoff; **2022** rapid hikes), capital tends to prefer USD assets and the **USD strengthens** broadly—USD/SGD rises even if MAS is tightening. Conversely, when U.S. rate pressure fades, USD/SGD typically falls. citeturn8search5turn0search12turn0search7

3) **Risk-on / risk-off and growth cycles.**  
Global **risk-off** spikes (GFC **2008–09**; COVID **2020**) lift the USD as a safe haven; **risk-on** phases strengthen SGD as trade and regional growth recover. MAS policy responded counter-cyclically in 2008–09 and 2020 (flatten/re-centre), cushioning volatility but not fully offsetting global tides. citeturn7search9turn7search13

4) **Singapore’s strong external position.**  
Singapore runs a persistent **current-account surplus** (≈**17–18% of GDP** in 2024; S$ **34.8bn** in Q2-2025), structurally supportive of the SGD and consistent with the long-run USD/SGD decline. citeturn0search3turn0search8

---

## Political channels that mattered (and how much)

- **U.S. policy & credibility shocks** (debt-ceiling brinkmanship; credit-rating downgrades in **2011**, **2023**, **2025**): these can **briefly** dent the USD, but the **dominant** driver has been **rate differentials** and growth. Still, they contribute to episodic USD softness/two-way volatility. citeturn9search12turn9search0turn9news22

- **Trade policy shifts** (e.g., U.S.–China frictions 2018–19; renewed tariff uncertainty in 2025): they influence Singapore’s manufacturing/trade cycle and therefore MAS stance. Example: MAS **eased in Oct-2019** amid trade-war-linked slowdown; in **2025** MAS trimmed the slope as external demand softened. citeturn8search8turn3news20

- **Singapore’s institutional stability.**  
MAS’s **credible, rules-based** exchange-rate framework—and its shift to **quarterly policy statements from 2024**—anchors inflation expectations and reduces currency risk premia, a political-institutional advantage that supports SGD over the long run. citeturn10search6turn10search5

---

## Bottom line

- Over **2005→2025**, **USD/SGD fell ≈22%** (SGD strengthened), with **three major USD strength waves** (GFC, 2015–16 liftoff, 2022 Fed shock) temporarily reversing the broader trend. The **single best explainer** is the interaction of **MAS’s S$NEER policy** (a gentle appreciation bias over time) with **global U.S. dollar cycles** driven by **U.S. rates and risk sentiment**; politics (debt/ratings/trade) add **episodic** noise but are **secondary** to those macro forces. citeturn5view0turn4view0turn3search2turn0search7

---

### Key turning points (quick reference)
- **Oct-2008 → Apr-2009:** MAS flattened slope; later **re-centred lower** to support growth during GFC. USD/SGD up, then down. citeturn7search9turn7search6  
- **Jan & Oct-2015; Apr-2016:** MAS **cut slope** twice; then set **0% slope**; alongside Fed liftoff → USD/SGD higher. citeturn8search0turn8search2  
- **2020:** MAS **0% slope** + re-centring lower; pandemic risk-off → USD/SGD firm. citeturn7search13  
- **Oct-2021 → Oct-2022:** **Five** MAS tightenings; still, USD strong on Fed hikes; USD/SGD elevated. citeturn0search6turn0search7  
- **2024:** MAS on hold; USD/SGD eased with softer USD. citeturn10search14  
- **Jan-2025:** MAS **eases** (slope trimmed); **Jul-2025:** hold; USD/SGD now ~1.29. citeturn3news20turn3news21turn4view0

---

### What to watch (forward-looking, 6–18 months)
- **U.S.–Singapore yield gap**: biggest single swing factor for USD/SGD.  
- **MAS stance**: after 2025’s slope trims, any further easing (or a re-centring) would skew toward a **firmer USD/SGD**; a renewed inflation uptick would do the opposite. citeturn3news20turn3news21  
- **Trade & geopolitics**: tariff paths and China’s growth pulse feed through Singapore’s cycle and MAS decisions—politics matter **via** economics.

items.title: Singapore central bank eases monetary policy, first time since March 2020
items.snippet: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has loosened its monetary policy for the first time since March 2020 due to slower-than-expected inflation and economic growth. The central bank, which controls monetary policy through the exchange rate, has slightly reduced the slope of the S$NEER policy band, allowing for a modest appreciation of the Singapore dollar. Core inflation is now forecasted between 1.0% and 2.0% for 2025, down from the previously expected 1.5% to 2.5%. Headline inflation forecasts remain at 1.5%-2.5%. Singapore's GDP growth was 4% in 2024, surpassing the initial projection of 3.5%, but is expected to slow to 1%-3% in 2025. This decision marks a significant shift as MAS had tightened policy five times since October 2021 to combat pandemic-related inflation and geopolitical uncertainties. The Singapore dollar stabilized against the U.S. dollar, and the domestic stock index rose by 0.7% following the announcement.

supporting_websites.title: Singapore keeps monetary policy unchanged as trade tensions ease
supporting_websites.snippet:
Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has decided to maintain its current monetary policy, keeping the rate of appreciation of its exchange rate-based policy band unchanged. This decision comes amid improved global trade conditions and stronger-than-expected economic growth in the second quarter, which showed a 1.4% quarter-on-quarter GDP increase, helping the country avoid a technical recession. The choice to maintain policy contrasts with analyst expectations, which were evenly split between a policy hold and further easing.

MAS cited easing trade tensions and more stable financial conditions since April as factors reducing the need for additional stimulus. Despite this, uncertainties remain, particularly around 2026, and Singapore’s growth is expected to slow in the latter half of 2025 as the impact of frontloaded exports wanes. Core inflation has dropped to 0.6% year-on-year in June 2025 from 5.5% in early 2023. While OCBC and Maybank economists noted two-way inflation risks from tariff impacts and geopolitical shifts, Maybank forecasted Singapore’s 2025 GDP growth at 3.2%, higher than the government's current 0.0–2.0% projection.

supporting_websites.title: The United States loses its triple-A credit rating at Moody's over rising federal debt
supporting_websites.snippet: On May 16, 2025, Moody's downgraded the United States' credit rating from Aaa to Aa1, citing rising federal debt and interest costs. This marked the loss of the last triple-A rating the U.S. held, following previous downgrades by Fitch Ratings in 2023 and S&P Global Ratings in 2011. Moody's explained that successive administrations and Congress have repeatedly failed to implement effective measures to curb large budget deficits and rising entitlement costs, projecting continuing fiscal deterioration over the next decade. Despite the downgrade, Moody’s shifted the U.S. outlook from negative to stable, acknowledging the nation’s strong institutional framework, large and resilient economy, and the U.S. dollar’s global reserve status. President Donald Trump has vowed to reduce the national debt, which has surpassed $36 trillion. Countries maintaining Aaa ratings with Moody’s include the European Union, Canada, and Germany, while Austria and Finland share the new Aa1 rating with the U.S.
